metadata.origin: Introduced from Asian chestnut trees imported to New York
metadata.description: The American chestnut was once the dominant tree of Eastern forests, comprising up to 25% of hardwood trees. The blight killed an estimated 3-4 billion trees.
sources: Freinkel, Susan. 'American Chestnut: The Life, Death, and Rebirth of a Perfect Tree' (2007)
Anagnostakis, Sandra L. 'Chestnut Blight: The Classical Problem of an Introduced Pathogen' (1987)

pre_blight_ecology.forest_composition: American chestnut comprised 25-30% of Southern Appalachian hardwood forests
economic_importance: Primary source of tannin for leather industry
Rot-resistant lumber for construction, fencing, railroad ties
Nuts as food source for humans, livestock, and wildlife
Reliable annual nut crop (unlike oaks which mast irregularly)
ecological_role: Major food source for deer, bear, turkey, squirrels, and other wildlife
Consistent annual mast crop provided reliable food
Dominant canopy tree in mixed hardwood forests
Supported unique insect and fungal communities

major_events.description: Forester Hermann Merkel identifies unusual cankers killing chestnut trees at the Bronx Zoo
Mycologist William Murrill identifies the fungus causing the blight
Blight spreading rapidly through Pennsylvania forests
First organized scientific effort to combat the blight
Southern spread accelerating down the Appalachian chain
Scientists tracking southward progression of blight front

major_events.event: First blight cases in NC mountains
major_events.description: Chestnut blight confirmed in North Carolina mountain counties
Blight established throughout the Black Mountain region
Large-scale death of chestnut trees accelerating
Black Mountain College opens as chestnut blight transforms surrounding forests
Majority of mature American chestnuts dead or dying
American chestnut functionally extinct as a canopy tree in Southern Appalachians
Entire native range affected; estimated 3-4 billion trees dead
